content: The Act may be cited as the "Engineering Biology Research and Development Act of 2015". The Congress finds that cellular and molecular processes can be utilized to develop new products, processes, and systems that benefit society, enhance national security, and boost the economy. Engineering biology requires a diverse set of skills and long-term research and development to achieve breakthroughs, necessitating government investment. The Federal Government can facilitate the development of tools and technologies for engineering biology through long-term research and development, as industry support alone is insufficient due to the distant or uncertain benefits. Multiple user facilities can be supported by the Federal Government to advance engineering biology. The Federal Government can play a crucial role in advancing engineering biology by supporting the development of tools and technologies through multiple user facilities. Other countries' investments in this field pose a risk to the United States' competitive edge, necessitating the need for a National Engineering Biology Initiative. A National Engineering Biology Initiative is crucial for the United States to maintain its competitive edge in the field, as other countries are heavily investing in engineering biology. This initiative can establish new research directions, improve coordination, drive technology transfer, and ensure optimal returns on the Federal investment. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Advisory Committee" refers to the committee designated under section 5, "biomanufacturing" is the manufacturing of products using biological technologies, "engineering biology" is the science and engineering of cellular and molecular processes to develop new products, and "Interagency Committee" refers to another committee. The term "engineering biology" refers to the science and engineering of cellular and molecular processes to develop new products, processes, and systems that will contribute significantly to societal well-being, national security, and the economy. The term "Interagency Committee" refers to the committee designated under section 4(e), and the term "Program" refers to the National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program established under section 4. The National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program is established under section 4. SEC. 5. ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The President shall designate an advisory committee on engineering biology research and development with at least 12 members from various sectors to assess the progress, need for revisions, balance of activities and funding, and the effectiveness of Program priorities in maintaining US leadership in engineering biology. The Advisory Committee on engineering biology research and development will assess the progress, need for revisions, balance of activities and funding, Program priorities' effectiveness in maintaining US leadership, management, coordination, implementation, and ethical considerations within 3 years. The Advisory Committee on engineering biology research and development will assess the Program's leadership, management, coordination, implementation, and ethical considerations every 3 years and report findings to relevant authorities. The Advisory Committee will report its assessment findings and recommendations for Program improvement every 5 years to the President and relevant congressional committees. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to this Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. EXTERNAL REVIEW OF ETHICAL, LEGAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIETAL ISSUES. The Director of the National Science Foundation will convene a workshop with the National Academies to review ethical, legal, environmental, and societal issues related to engineering biology research. The workshop aims to assess current research, identify gaps, and provide recommendations within 12 months of the Act's enactment. A report to Congress is due within 2 years. The workshop convened by the Director of the National Science Foundation aims to assess current research, identify gaps, and provide recommendations on engineering biology research issues. A summary report will be transmitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. AGENCY ACTIVITIES.
